Representing a broad range of clients including the leading corporates of the region, our clients are at the heart of our practice.
data.text:
Our latest KnowledgeShare Alert discusses the new regulatory framework targeted at social media services and Internet messaging service providers with at least eight million users in Malaysia that was introduced on 1 August 2024. The primary objective of the regulatory framework is to create a safer online environment for users in Malaysia, especially children and those vulnerable to online harm, and to combat the rise of cybercrimes in Malaysia. It seeks to hold the relevant service providers accountable in conducting their business operations in Malaysia, including effectively managing harmful content and strengthening processes to curb cybercrimes committed on their platforms. Should you have any queries as to how this development may affect your business, please do not hesitate to get in touch with your usual contact at Rahmat Lim & Partners or Yee Ling (Karen) Foong. This article has been prepared with the assistance of Senior Associate Hong Syuen Ng and Associate Yung Jia Heng. https://lnkd.in/gx7N-6cT #RahmatLimandPartners #MCMCLicensing #SocialMediaServices #InternetMessagingServiceProviders

Our latest KnowledgeShare Alert discusses the Arbitration (Amendment) Bill 2024 and the Construction Industry Payment and Adjudication (Amendment) Bill 2024 (collectively, the “Bills”) which has been passed by the Senate (Dewan Negara) on 24 July 2024. The Bills will be presented for Royal Assent and become law upon their publication in the Federal Gazette of Malaysia. This Alert sets out the key changes introduced by the Bills. Should you have any queries as to how this development may affect your business, please do not hesitate to get in touch with your usual contact at Rahmat Lim & Partners, Kamilah Kasim or Yap Yeow Han. Rahmat Lim & Partners is pleased to announce the strengthening of our Technology, Media and Telecommunications (TMT) practice. In response to the industry's rising emphasis on emerging technologies such as AI and fintech, we have revised our focus on the TMT practice by assembling a cohesive and collaborative cross-departmental practice comprising lawyers from our Regulatory and Compliance department and our Intellectual Property and Technology department. The core team members of our TMT practice are Partner Yee Ling (Karen) Foong, Managing Partner Azman bin Othman Luk, Partner Pauline Khor, and Senior Associate Hong Syuen Ng. Karen Foong advises on financial regulatory and fintech matters. She advises multinational banks, fintech companies, e-commerce companies, payment processors, and technological service providers on the licensing, regulatory, and compliance issues applicable to their products and services. Karen also has experience in handling telecommunications licensing matters, including the offering of various connectivity, co-location, and data centre-related services. Besides advising on finance law, Azman bin Othman Luk regularly advises on regulatory issues in the TMT sector, including telecommunications network licensing requirements, data centre establishment, cloud storage, and electronic contracts. In addition, he has experience in advising financial institutions in relation to IT turnkey projects and service agreements. He has given various talks on electronic signatures and evidence, and authored the chapter on Electronic Evidence in Halsbury's Laws of Malaysia (2009 edition) published by Lexis Nexis. Pauline has experience developing IP strategies and policies, which are critical in the TMT sector. She also oversees IP portfolios, drafts and negotiates IP agreements, and advises on biotechnology matters and complex IP-centric due diligence and transactions in the technology sector. Prior to rejoining the Firm, Hong Syuen was a Senior Associate at another large Malaysian law firm with an established practice focusing on TMT law. Hong Syuen advises on a spectrum of IT contracts, ranging from regional IT turnkey agreements to business-as-usual IT contracts. Her capability also extends to advising on intellectual property issues entwined with technology, technology disputes and telecommunications contracts. She co-authored the chapter on Year in Review: Technology Disputes in Malaysia (2023 edition) published by Lexology. As part of the Allen & Gledhill network known as A&G Asia, we have access to a highly regarded regional TMT practice, whose lawyers are recognised by Chambers Global and The Legal 500, amongst other publications. This association allows us to leverage our regional experience in multi-jurisdictional TMT matters. With our collective experience, we look forward to providing our clients with seamless support and holistic advice to address their current projects and future needs in the TMT sector.

Our latest KnowledgeShare Alert discusses the Personal Data Protection (Amendment) Bill 2024 (“PDP Bill”) which was recently passed in the House of Representatives (Dewan Rakyat). The PDP Bill must still be passed by the Senate (Dewan Negara), and the Yang di-Pertuan Agong must assent before the PDP Bill can come into force. The PDP Bill will amend the Personal Data Protection Act 2010 to enhance the processing of personal data framework to be in line with international standards and practice. Should you have any queries as to how this development may affect your business, please do not hesitate to get in touch with your usual contact at Rahmat Lim & Partners, or Penny Wong.
